Take Home Exercise 3: Modelling Geography of Financial Inclusion in Tanzania with Geographically Weighted Methods

Author

Sei Sar Hla Kyi

Published

October 14, 2024

Modified

October 21, 2024

1 Overview

1.1 Background

Financial inclusion plays a critical role in fostering equitable economic growth by enabling individuals and businesses to access essential financial services such as banking, loans, equity, and insurance. It is especially important in developing regions where the unbanked population faces limited access to formal financial products, which constrains their ability to save, invest, and secure insurance, leading to income inequality. In this study, we aim to explore the factors that influence financial inclusion at the district level in Tanzania using Geographically Weighted Regression (GWR) methods.

GWR is a powerful spatial analysis tool that accounts for geographical variability in relationships between predictor variables and financial inclusion, providing localized insights into how different factors affect access to financial services across districts.

1.2 Objectives

The primary goal of this analysis is to identify and examine the key indicators of financial inclusion in Tanzania.

1.3 Defining Financial Inclusion

2 Loading R Packages

  • Packages Used
  • Code

The following packages were used for this study:

Package Description
tidyverse For non-spatial data wrangling
corrplot For correlation analysis among chosen variables
sf For importing, managing, and handling geospatial data
sfdep To derive tourism economy indicator layer
tmap For visualizing maps
ggplot2 To visualize other statistics 
pacman::p_load(olsrr, ggstatsplot, ggpubr, sf, spdep, sfdep, GWmodel, tmap, tidyverse, gtsummary,see,performance,datawizard)

3.2 Import the Data

3.2.1 Aspatial Data

The FinScope Tanzania dataset from 2023, was imported by using read_csv() package.

Then, the data was prepared for analysis with the following steps:

  • Remove columns with all missing/NA values.
tanzania <- read_csv("data/rawdata/FinScope_Tanzania.csv")

Lastly, we will save the prepared dataframe into rds format.

  • Save
  • Load
write_rds(tanzania, "data/rds/tanzania.rds")
tanzania <- read_rds("data/rds/tanzania.rds")

3.2.2 Geospatial Data - Study Area

The geo Boundaries of Tanzania dataset, was imported by using st_read() package.

The dataset was prepared for analysis with the following steps:

tanzbounds <- st_read(dsn = "data/rawdata/", 
                      layer = "geoBoundaries-TZA-ADM2")
Reading layer `geoBoundaries-TZA-ADM2' from data source 
  `/Users/seesarhlakyi/Desktop/ssrhk/ISSS626-GAA/Take-home_Ex/Take-home_Ex03/data/rawdata' 
  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
Simple feature collection with 170 features and 5 fields
Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 29.58953 ymin: -11.76235 xmax: 40.44473 ymax: -0.983143
Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84
st_crs(tanzbounds)
Coordinate Reference System:
  User input: WGS 84 
  wkt:
GEOGCRS["WGS 84",
    ENSEMBLE["World Geodetic System 1984 ensemble",
        MEMBER["World Geodetic System 1984 (Transit)"],
        MEMBER["World Geodetic System 1984 (G730)"],
        MEMBER["World Geodetic System 1984 (G873)"],
        MEMBER["World Geodetic System 1984 (G1150)"],
        MEMBER["World Geodetic System 1984 (G1674)"],
        MEMBER["World Geodetic System 1984 (G1762)"],
        MEMBER["World Geodetic System 1984 (G2139)"],
        ELLIPSOID["WGS 84",6378137,298.257223563,
            LENGTHUNIT["metre",1]],
        ENSEMBLEACCURACY[2.0]],
    PRIMEM["Greenwich",0,
        ANGLEUNIT["degree",0.0174532925199433]],
    CS[ellipsoidal,2],
        AXIS["geodetic latitude (Lat)",north,
            ORDER[1],
            ANGLEUNIT["degree",0.0174532925199433]],
        AXIS["geodetic longitude (Lon)",east,
            ORDER[2],
            ANGLEUNIT["degree",0.0174532925199433]],
    USAGE[
        SCOPE["Horizontal component of 3D system."],
        AREA["World."],
        BBOX[-90,-180,90,180]],
    ID["EPSG",4326]]
  • Save
  • Load
write_rds(tanzbounds, "data/rds/tanzbounds.rds")
tanzbounds<- read_rds("data/rds/tanzbounds.rds")
